This is a small robot using my previous things (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:923605) and (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941230).

It is powered by an Arduino nano and a ESP8266 providing WIFI connectivity. There's also an IMU and 3 ultrasonic sensors.

Firmware available here : https://github.com/laurent-fr/W3W-Bot (updated with display support)

UPDATE 15/08/2015 : Pin swap on motor3 (W3W-Bot.sch), adding display support

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FhN_-Y1UXZE

First, build http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:923605 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941230

You will need to modify 3 standard hobby servos :

  • modify the main gear to allow continous rotation
  • remove the electronics
  • add a L9110H and a capacitor as shown in diagram 'w3w-bot-motors'
  • add a 4-wire cable (about 20cm length) with a dupont connector

On the first floor, you will need :

  • 1x 2Ah 2s LiPo Battery
  • 1x toggle switch (drill a hole on the platform as shown in the picture)
  • 1x 3A 5V switching regulator
  • 1x 1A 3.3V switching regulator

See the diagram 'w3w-bot-psu'

On the second floor, you will need :

  • 1x Arduino nano
  • 1x GY-85 9-dof IMU
  • 1x ESP8266-01 Wifi module
  • 3x HC-SR04 ultrasonic module
  • 1x i2c 0.96" OLED Display (128x64), yellow/white
  • 3x 12cm 4-wire cable with dupont connectors
  • 1x perfboard (mine is 4x6cm)

Use pictures and schematic 'w3w-bot' ( hint: for 1.8K resistors I used SMD on copper side of the breadboard )

Software:

The firmware is available at https://github.com/laurent-fr/W3W-Bot

  • first program the ESP8266 with esp8266-telnet (serial to wifi/telnet), don't forget to update your WIFI SSID and password
  • program the arduino with compass-calibration.ino and run with the serial monitor, you will obtain 4 lines to update in config.h of the main program
  • then program the main firmware on the arduino ('robot' folder')

When powered on, the robot should turn to magnetic north after a few seconds, and stay in this position (try to rotate the robot by hand).

Then you should be able to telnet the robot (the IP address is displayed on the first line of the screen) , for now there are a few simple commands (all the angles are in degrees) :

  • H : change the main heading of the robot
  • A : set the angle when the robot is moving
  • S : set the speed of the robot (0 to about 60)
  • B : get the battery status (0% to 100%)
  • E<1 to 3> : get the the distance to the next obstacle for the given sonar (in cm)

Updated bed corners for 3mm thick glass bed for FlashForge Dreamer. I moved the holes for the screws because they weren't perfectly aligned to fit on the Dreamer bed. Also added a nut hole, for those who do not want to tamper with their bed, hence you will need two additional M3 nuts. Or you could use two M3 fine thread wingnuts instead. I must remind you that these corners don't put any pressure on the top of the glass, they only keep it in place.

Additional requirements:
2 M3 nuts or
2 M3 fine thread wingnuts

Installation is pretty simple. Just put the corners in place, tighten them down with the nuts and you're good to go.

title: Trump 2016 Presidential Campaign Pin Make America Great Again!!!!

description.text:
Trump 2016!!! Get your America on with this one and only 3D printed Trump 2016 Presidential Pin! Make America Great Again!

Here are some great words of wisdom the Donald has imparted to us

"I will be the greatest jobs president that God ever created"
"When was the last time anybody saw us beating, let’s say, China in a trade deal? They kill us. I beat China all the time"
"Free trade is terrible. Free trade can be wonderful if you have smart people. But we have stupid people"

This design was based off the most awesome mock photo for Trump 2016 which is also attached with this item. Do not know who made it but am giving out credit for basis of idea.

MADE IN THE U S OF A

You can go to a craft software and get adhesive backed safety pins to make these full out campaign pins.

Some of these items are made in multiple parts and can be nested into each other. Based on the Circular back you print you can get different aspects of the logo.This is for if you do not have a multi head printer you can still get multiple colors. I also have a full joined piece for others that want a single print. If you really want the native files I can load these as well.

Hair and Main are items that can be nested into a circle if you want. I have both of these models to have ability to be nested into either circle to give positive or negative effect. If you are having clearance issues, try scaling in your software when doing individual pieces that nest in main circle, nesting pieces have tight clearances.

Have fun!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

comments.text: How much would I need to scale this up to make it an octave lower?
comments.author: slipperyskates

comments.text: You need to double the height of the instrument, but it won't fit most printers. Even the first one barely fits on mine
comments.author: slipperyskates

comments.text: So it would just need double the volume?  I could scale x y and z by the cube root of 2 (1.26), or I could scale x and y only by a factor of the square root of 2 (1.414).  I agree I don't want to print this thing any taller for the sake of time, even though the rostock will do 15" or so.  This was already the tallest thing i've printed :p
comments.author: NilsRoe

comments.text: The length of each individual tube determines the pitch. So if you scaled the Z axis by another 100%, you'd get a lower octave in total.
comments.author: slipperyskates

comments.text: I would have though volume would have something to do with it too.  Just blew on a 2 liter bottle that's maybe 1.5 times the length of the G4 pipe, and getting a G2.  Of course the bottle has a relatively huge volume and opening far smaller than the diameter so I realize it's not directly comparable to a pure cylindrical shape.  This is really intriguing me right now, do you have any good resources on this kind of thing you could share?

This is a little pegboard mount that interfaces with Loc Lines. I use these for all kinds of stuff like helping hands, etc... so I figured it would be handy to make a little interface for my pegboard. I plan to use it for LED lighting, as well as mounting my mobius action camera to record print time lapses, etc...

The loc lines can be purchased on amazon for a little over $7 for 6. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008O14864?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00

You can actually unsnap and snap sections apart/together to make them different lengths.

Print Settings:
Print with a .25 layer height, use support, a 5mm raft, and 2mm brim.

The loc lines can be purchased on amazon for a little over $7 for 6. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008O14864?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00

You can actually unsnap and snap sections apart/together to make them different lengths.

Box to hold the neutral and earth BUS bars used in my home automation system. Designed to hold brass BUS bar which is 160mm long X 9mm wide X 12mm high and has 22 terminals. The 2 end terminals are used to secure the bar to the housing, the lid is held on with 2 small screws. Total size of unit when finished is 502mm long x 122mm wide X 50mm high. The one in the photos was printed on a Robo 3D R1 printer which has a large print area, check your machine will print an item this size before starting!!

description.text: Had a very loose magnetic catch on one of our cupboards which, on inspection was actually broken (see pictures). The magnet was fine as was the back piece that holds the magnet. So please with this model as it worked straight off the machine and the print seen above is on low quality as it was simply the prototype. It is a little weak so I may print again but the little cylinder in the middle and general fit were spot on. OpenSCAD file included so you can tweak if you feel the urge.

Distribution box used in the home automation system to connect all the low voltage systems into using 1 power supply. Gives 12 outlets from a single supply. There is a small hole in the centre to fit a 3mm LED power on indicator if needed. I used these chassis mount plugs from amazon http://www.amazon.co.uk/2-1mm-Chasis-Female-Socket-Connector/dp/B00WZ83FK2/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1439398875&sr=8-3-fkmr0&keywords=2.1MM+X+5.5MM+PANEL+CHASSIS+MOUNT+DC+SOCKET+CHARGER+POWER+JACK+PLUG+-+SMALL

Molds in shapes of tetris blocks, originally intended for icecubes. I didn't manage to make a non-leaking print, maybe these can be used for flour or so.

The source code is organized so you can 'configure' the shapes that you want, by enabling and disabling walls.

In Slic3r, choose top layers 0 and 0% infill. I used vertical layers 2 and 3-4 bottom layers.

Disclaimer: use at your own risk, our filaments can be toxic for food use!

update: I printed it using ABS. After glueing the bottom from the outside with 'ABS juice', it doesn't seem to leak anymore :-)

comments.text: I think the main issue here would be the existence of small holes, which might get filled up with bacteria over time. in that sense, I'm not sure any 3d printed object is really "food safe" unless fully sealed and/or polished somehow. as long as it's only used with frozen water though, it's hard to imagine real health issues.

title: FolgerTech Kossel Magnetic Upgrade (OBSOLETE - SEE V2!)

description.text:
THIS DESIGN IS OBSOLETE - Please see my "V2" re-design:
VERSION 2 posted here! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1064124

UPDATE!** I have finally received my new 'countersunk' magnets and 10mm threaded steel balls... So I now have all the parts necessary to complete my re-design of this kit!!! I am working on the new design and will be uploading the new design soon - I haven't decided yet whether to replace everything here, or to just create a new 'thing'... Either way, you'll be able to find the new 'kit' from this link... ;-)

That's all for my update right now, LOL!



Back to the existing comments for the 'current' project...

These are the objects I'm creating to upgrade my FolgerTech Kossel to Magnetic attachment.



Unfortunately This project isn't turning into much of an 'upgrade' as the magnets just don't hold as well as they should. (And these are SUPPOSED to be "N52" grade neodymium magnets.) It may just be that the gap is too much between the magnet and the ball bearing. I tried to minimize it to just .1mm, but for some reason, both Cura and Slic3r insisted on putting 3 or 4 .1mm layers in there... And .I haven't found a way to make that smaller as of yet. So for now, I extended my original 'Traxxas' ball-joint arms by ~70mm (for ~300MM total now) and re-installed the ball-joint setup into my printer.

If you have any tips on how to get that gap down to a single .1mm layer, please let me know

In the mean time, I'm probably going to re-think my design and put the ball bearings on the rods and mount 'dish' magnets on the effector and Carriages. (v1.5?)
Acually... V2 posted here! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1064124

Anyways, back to the notes about this 'thing' now...
One thing to note is that it doesn't support the original servo-mounted micro-switch bed leveling. I changed to FSR Bed leveling. - A link to the kit that I bought from eBay is included in "Parts Sources" at the bottom of the Instructions.

The Effector fits the "E3D V5 Clone" that came with my printer. I just bought a Genuine E3D V6, so I will be creating an effector for that as well, but for now, this one is tailored towards the V5 and/or clones.

UPDATE Everything seems to fit quite well, but I may need stronger magnets...

Ok, well these parts are working, but the magnets aren't holding as strong as I think they should. I think that either my gaps between the magnets and ball bearings are too big or my magnets aren't quite strong enough (They're SUPPOSED to be N52 grade, but I doubt they are, as the 6MMx10MM ones seem stronger than the 10mmx10mm ones -- stupid cheap Chinese magnets!!!).

So if the printer moves too fast, or the print head gets bumped, they come un-done relatively easy.

But, they ARE working, and I'm producing some nice accurate prints, but I am printing a bit slower than I was before (I'm trying a 60mm/s print now, and surprisingly', it seems to be doing quite well. (But I was printing at close to 200mm/s with the stock Traxxas rod ends. - albeit a little lower quality, but it could handle it!)
Update: The 60mm/s print failed as one of the magnets disconnected mid-print.
So I think I'm going to have to re-design this upgrade, as printing SLOWER was certainly not my objective...

All parts are designed to print with NO SUPPORT necessary!

I printed the Carriages and Rod Ends in PLA at .1MM layer height with a .2MM nozzle and 60% infill.

I am currently printing the Effector in PLA as well, at .2MM layer height with a.3MM nozzle and 60% infill and it looks like it's coming out perfect so far. (If I need to decrease the nozzle size of layer height, I'll update this text)

Carriage Status: COMPLETE
This is my Magnetic Carriage design that is designed to use 10MMx10MM cylindrical Neodymium magnets from eBay (source at bottom).

It has integrated GT2 belt grips and Opto End-Stop tails. The end-stop tails can be snipped off if you're using microswitch end-stops, or even shortened a bit if they're too long for you.

It requires M3-16MM screws for all four mounting holes.

When installing the magnets, be sure to orient the magnetic poles all in the same direction. This is because I'm using a dual-magnet configuration - one on the Carriage to hold the steel ball bearing, and the other on the Rod to hold the Rod to the Ball Bearing. Use one of the other magnets to attract the magnet you're inserting into the 'sleeve' for the magnet on the Carriage. Repeat for all 6 mounts.

Rod Ends Status: COMPLETE
These are designed for use with 6MM OD Carbon Fiber rods and 6MM Diameter x 10MM Long Neodymium Magnets. (sources at bottom)

Make sure you've matched the magnetic pole that's attracted to your ball bearing (when mounted in the Carriage), then simply slide it into the Rod End, then press the Carbon Fiber rod in. Note that the orientation of the magnets is critical due to my 'dual magnet' design. Setup both ends of the Rods with the same configuration, so they'll work either way.

I'd recommend test-fitting everything before glueing. Most of my rods seem to fit pretty tight, but a few were a bit loose (strange), If they fit pretty tight, you might be able to get away without gluing them. But I would do it anyways!

I was going to create a jig to do this, but I just press fit the magnets in all the way and then press fit the carbon fiber rod into the rod end. Note: This technique worked for all but one, which I guess I didn't clean up well enough, so I had to split the rod ends, then adjust the magnet and rod spacing and glue them back on.

Effector WIP Complete and tested, but the magnets need to be stronger or hold better.

As with the Carriages, when installing the magnets, be sure to orient the magnetic poles all in the same direction, and match those of the Carriages! Again, this is because I'm using a dual-magnet configuration - one on the Effector to hold the steel ball bearing, and the other on the Rod to hold the Rod to the Ball Bearing. Use one of the other magnets to attract the magnet you're inserting into the 'sleeve' for the magnet on the Effector. Repeat for all 6 mounts.

Re-mix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:388342

Note: Once I figure out a stronger magnetic attachment, I'll create a second version of this Effector that will move the magnet mounts down nearer to the nozzle. It will still clamp the top of the Hotend, but will also 'clamp' the bottom of the Hotend cooling fins. It will have integrating cooling ducts as well as integrated PLA duct(s) and maybe even space for the LED Ring to mount.
I'll create at least a couple versions:
   One for the "All-Metal" hotend that came with my kit (A clone of the E3D v5)
   An E3D V6 version (since I just bought a real one!)
;-)

Parts Sources:
FSR Bed Leveling Kit:
http://www.tridprinting.com/Electronics/#3D-Printer-FSR-Controller-Kit

Neodymium Magnets:
10MM Diameter x 10MM Long: (Carriages and Effector) http://www.ebay.com/itm/251866246234
6MM Diameter x 10MM Long: (Rods) http://www.ebay.com/itm/291497493062

Carbon Fiber Rods: http://www.ebay.com/itm/311162030839

Chrome Ball Bearings: http://www.ebay.com/itm/301017875599

description.text:
I created these to upgrade my FolgerTech Kossel to Optical End-stops.

They mount right to the 2020 extrusion using a M3-8mm or M3-10mm screw and drop-in T-Nut.

I printed these in PLA with a .4MM nozzle and .3MM layer height at 60% fill, but I'm sure other settings would work well too.

The Opto mounts to it with a couple of M3-10MM screws threaded right into the plastic. (Don't tighten them too much or you'll start to strip the hole, just snug them up.)

It also works to hold the standard microswitch end-stops, but you can't access the adjustment/mount screw with them mounted.

author: Hagster

description.text: A dough docker for making indentations in dough.

This thing is called a dough docker. It puts indentations in bread dough. This prevents large dough-bubbles from forming when it is baked in the oven.

The spikes are not supposed to actually pierce through the dough. Instead, it presses the top and bottom surfaces of the dough together, and they stick in those spots.

I needed something for homemade pizza, and this works really well. The design is more or less copied from certain types of commercial dockers. Search for photos.

The wheels are a loose fit and turn easily.

On mine, I alternated a spacer with a wheel so the holes are not too close together, but one might spread the wheels farther apart, or closer together as required. Just print more, or fewer, spacers and wheels.

The axle should be friction-tight enough to stay in the frame, but if not, there's a small hole on the axle's end, where a cotter pin or piece of wire will secure it in place.

Metric files are provided.

description.text:
This is a very simple Absinthe Fountain and another trial on how water -tight PLA or ABS is. The way you use it is by filling the icebox half way with water and freezing it. The ice box then goes on top of the base and then the ice water drips down and slowly comes out of the pipes on the base; which then drips into the glasses.

Absinthe only really needs to fill the bubble of the glass. You can use some blue-tac to block the pipes that aren't in use. Can serve up to 4 glasses at a time. Please Enjoy.

The gears make the wrist move back and forth.
The holes in the palm are for zip-ties, and it simulates the collapsing motion of the palm.
You will need both .dxf files.

(1) Let's start with the hand_no_wrist_or_arm.dxf file. The palm is split into two parts (1 part for the four fingers, and 1 part for the thumb and wrist connection).
(1.a) Utilize one 1-slot/1-hole pieces in each of the finger slots, and two of them for the thumb slot (attach using wood glue or equivalent)
(1.b) Utilize two 2-hole pieces for the next finger-join on each of the fingers (one on both sides of the hole resulting from the pieces from 1.a), and just one for the thumb (attach using nuts and bolts or equivalent)
(1.c) Utilize one 2-hole pieces for the next finger-join on each of the fingers (one in between the pieces resulting from 1.b) (attach using nuts and bolts or equivalent)
(1.d) Utilize both 1-slot/2-hole pieces for the wrist slots (attach using wood glue or equivalent)

(2) Let's move on to wrist_and_arm.dxf
(2.a) In my build, I used dowel segments to provide the rod around which the gears could rotate. If you use the same, utilize the circular pieces and caps for either end of the rod. For now, attach caps only to one end of each of the 7 rods you will need. (utilize wood glue or equivalent)
(2.b) slide all seven rod/1-cap's into one of the frames.
(2.c) put the big-gear with two small holes onto the rod on the smaller end of the frame (this will attach to your wrist), and then fill in with an alternating big-gear/small-gear pattern
(2.d) place the second frame over the gears (should make a frame-gears-frame sandwich
(2.e) at this point some length of rod should be poking out from the frame-gears-frame sandwich, so attach caps to each of these
(2.f) place the big-gear with two holes in between the wrist pieces from your hand assembly, and connect using nuts and bolts or equivalent

Happy fabricating!

title: Quick CNC table positioning with spider coupler adapter

description.text:
Spider coupler adapter for use in manually repositioning a CNC milling machine table. This is handy when only the lead screw portion of the spider coupler is attached. The other portion is usually still attached to a stepper motor. You can use one or the other of these adapter heads depending on whether the elastomeric junction (rubbery part in between the two ends) is or is not on the metal coupler connected to the lead screw. When the table is snugged in for alignment and is in the position that you need it to be in then reattach the stepper motor. Useful after a tear-down for maintenance or to check travel of table before reconnecting the stepper.

Glue/acetone weld base (screw driver) portion to the adapter head.

Used on a Central Machinery Micro mill with a
Littlemachineshop.com CNC retrofit that uses Standard Lovejoy spider couplers (L-050 0.250).

Change the driver head on the adapter to anything that you would prefer other than a screw driver. Perhaps a hex head of a power screw driver or even a ratchet with an extender.

----- Project notes -----

CAD: Truespace V7.61

Platform: Up!3d using ABS 0.75 filament, fast mode, 200 micron resolution at near 90% fill (for added torsional strength).

Art to part time: 45min (including measurement,design and printing).

Testing of part: Worked as designed. Groove for blade of screw driver doesn't need to be so deep. used with power screw driver.

After seeing Zheng3's penny mortar idea, I thought that it would be possible to take a similar concept and make it into a ballista-like version. Until I print this myself I am not entirely sure if the tolerances are correct and everything is sized exactly. Give it a shot and I hope y'all like it!

To make 1 Desktop Ballista Print*:

1-Ballista 2.stl

1-ballista slider.stl

at least 1-Ballista Projectile.stl

UPDATE: I just added a file that has all three parts in the same .stl

.stl measurements are in cm
50% infill would seem to be fitting

Extra supplies:

a few-rubber bands

Assembly...
1) cut a rubber band to make it into one strand
2)slide the band through the hole on ballistaslider.stl
3) take each end of the band and tie them to each hole on the ballista frame
4) slide ballistaslider.stl into the groove of the ballista frame
5) place ballistaprojectile.stl on the groove of the frame

...pull the slider back and launch the projectile...

title: y belt holder vertical for prusa i3

description.text:
wilson ts y belt is by default oriented such that the teeth is perpendicular to x-y plane. I made this because I'm changing out the MDF board to aluminum carriage which comes with three SCV8UU and two holes in the center of the carriage 41mm apart to attach the y belt holder.

So I modified this vertical belt holder labeled as "ytable-8mm.stl" from mjrice link to that stl here: https://github.com/mjrice/wilson/commit/15bbdde62b79b8b839b46344a24383e9eda49e3a

I removed the rest of the table and leaving just the belt holder and added 41mm apart holes to attach to aluminum carriage

here's the amazon link to the aluminum y carriage I bought. Note that the printed part included has the teeth facing down perpendicular to y-z plane so this part is useless for wilson ts setup
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00THZJHJY?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00

Update1:
I also added "y belt holder offset.STL" if you use wilson ts, this offset is necessary so that the belt is aligned properly with the GT2 pulley and y tensioner
print at low quality

description.text:

Son necesarios tornillos M6x12 para el perfil con sus respectivas tuercas y tornillos M4x12 para atornillar el soporte a la fuente de alimentación

Support to snag a typical power supply 30A to an aluminum profile 30x30mm.
Profile M6x12 screws with their nuts and M4x12 screws are required to screw the bracket to the power supply

Se puede imprimir con ABS o PLA. Realmente no tiene que aguantar tanta tensión o peso como para que el PLA se quiebre.
Para acortar el tiempo a 0.25mm por capa se consiguen buenos resultados.

description.text:
Here is a printed prop that I designed with a key way so that the pieces slot together easily.  
Its rough looking but its printable and it works!  
Due to printing the prop side ways, It has high tensile strength.  
Although I wouldn't use these props on an expensive easy to break plane! You'll find out very quickly whether or not your print is going to hold or not. Roughly 1 out of 6 of mine exploded,or sheared on take off. But if it can handle take off then your pretty safe to fly!

The tricky part is getting the area and pitch of the blade right to pull it through the air. This would depend allot on what motor setup your running. A Low speed high torque configuration is probably more suited for printed props as they tend to flex and some times shatter at higher speeds under full load e.g. Take off. This creates allot of noise (which actually sounds kinda neat!) You get a buzzing humming bird kind of sound. Its ideal for my 3d plane (its a foamy) as it designed for doing low speed tricks, (Knife edge, Prop hang etc).Also buzzing sound is a great indication as to how much trust I'm giving it in the air.  
IMPORTANT: A dab of Super glue on the Inside overhang lips once its locked into position is a good idea. At high speed they tend to start tearing away from the center with out any support.

description.text:
I use a UD-3900 docking station everyday at work and I wanted to make something to make the dock a centerpiece. I was inspired by how spacestations grow over time as new modules are added.

The modular brackets can be stacked as needed and have holes to allow customizable arrangements of add-ons.

I like to have my phone, USBs, and pencils handy. so I created accessories to latch onto the docking station.

Read all about it here!
http://plugable.com/2015/08/18/customizable-desktop-battlestation

http://plugable.com/products/ud-3900
http://plugable.com/products/ud-3000

This adaptive device was designed for a boy without fingers on his left hand who plays a Bach Student Trumpet, model TR300.

The system is made up of five components;
(1) MAIN - surrounds and snaps onto the left side of the valves
(2) BOTTOM - slides over the base of the valves and main, snaps into place
(3) DOVETAIL - connects to the palm via two 1/8" barrel diameter Chicago screws, slides in and out of the main valve surround
(4) PALM - connects to both the dovetail and gauntlet via two 1/8" barrel diameter Chicago screws
(5) GAUNTLET - connects to the palm via two 1/8" barrel Chicago screws, slotted for Velcro attachment to arm

You can download the original size, built for a 10 year old, OR you can download scalable versions of the DOVETAIL, PALM, and GAUNTLET.

There are two different versions of the PALM - one that is full and must be printed on its "top," and one that can be printed in two parts and joined together with acetone or other adhesive method.

The trumpet with MAIN and BOTTOM attached, fits perfectly into the Bach trumpet case for easy storage after use.

This device was created during my 2015 Summer Fellowship, funded by the Enable Community Foundation, in the University of Wisconsin Milwaukee’s Digital Craft Research Lab.

For more information on this device visit my blog: http://digitalfabricationanddesign.blogspot.com/search/label/e-NABLE

However, I didn't like the handle in that design, because it didn't look at all like the original key. I therefore made my own adjustments to the file, so that the model looked a lot more like my imagination of the original part. I also added some embossed text ("Water" and "From Viktor") to the handle just to show off. Uploaded the model I gave away, and a clean one if you can keep the purpose of your keys in your head. SCAD-file is not parametric, but itÂ´s quiet obvious what to change if you have other dimensions than me. I know this is a kind of derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9636 , but I donÂ´t know how to make this apparent.
I printed mine with exterior support because of the overhang of the handle.

comments.author: stray77

comments.text: Upon closer inspection, they are using pin 26 (PB7) LED which is normally used to drive the yellow led.  Instead of tapping straight off the processor you can tap off the processor side of R22.  PB7 can be set for PWM Output C for Timer/Counter1.  As for the changes in Marlin, I'm gonna need some help.
comments.author: Gidim

comments.text:
You are right. Its PB7. Here is some more files to help in our design:
Gerber files for the board:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/9ljpy6rzaijmsu8/GT2560_GERBER.zip?dl=0
You can view them at this site ( or use GCPreview ) :
http://www.gerber-viewer.com/default.aspx
The silk doesnt show the R22 resistor, but it right close to PB7 and the LED. I also went over the schematic and the part DS ( http://www.atmel.com/images/atmel-2549-8-bit-avr-microcontroller-atmega640-1280-1281-2560-2561_datasheet.pdf )
and there are no other pines that I could find that are free and can output PWM.
So now we have the correct pin, we need to change the Merlin code to accommodate the auto level.
comments.author: stray77

comments.text:
from https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/blob/RC/Marlin/pins_ULTIMAKER.h
or if you're modifying geeetech firmware it would be in pins.h which can't easily be edited in the arduino ide, I use notepad++
comments.author: Gidim

comments.text:
I also use Notepad++, and will do the change ( when I get to this point ).
Why do you want to move Y axis? we are only changing the Z axis. Even then, im going to connect the switch in series ( the one on the head and the one at Zmin ) so if anything fails from the auto bed, the Zmin i will stop the Z axis from braking.
I don't think we need to do any other changes.
Do you have a new ver of the gerber files? That's all I could find and they look the same as the demo board.
comments.author: stray77

comments.text: I don't want to move the y axis but we're redefining pin 26 from its default of  #define Y_MIN_PIN 26 and we're using it for our servo signal #define SERVO0_PIN 26.  I need my y axis min endstop to continue to work so I swapped Y_MIN_PIN with Y_MAX_PIN so I can still use my Y axis min endstop, the only caveat being moving the plug to the Y-MAX port which will now function as Y-MIN. Since I don't use any X,Y or Z max endstops they are all unpopulated and available.
comments.author: Gidim

comments.text:
Here is the post the image came from http://www.geeetech.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=18&t=16923.
There is a 2nd image of the same mod by a 2nd person. Aside from that, no useful information is to be obtained from the geeetech forum. Unfortunately I can't explain how it's done or what modifications need to be done in marlin, however I'm just getting started. I'll post back any useful info I find. I would suggest trying irc.freenode.net: #reprap #marlin-firmware and #arduino for help.

title: Spill resistant coaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Yesterday, suffering from an extreme case of the dropsies I spilled a glass of wine and a glass of water on my desk within 5 minutes of each other. (It was the first glass of wine - no I was not drunk, just clumsy). That inspired this coaster with raised sides to reduce the likelihood of a small accidental bump from becoming a wet desk. I designed it in ViaCAD and have uploaded the source as well. I think next I'll make a variation that has an opening for a mug handle.
I printed it in PLA at .5mm and let slic3r make it hollow. It came out great, and in a couple intentional and unintentional tests so far it has performed flawlessly.

Have you ever felt like the molds that you had were limited? Like you were constrained to whatever the mold was? Or maybe you saw some great mold designs somewhere, but realized your printbed couldn't handle the size? No more. With these parametric tiles, you can mold what you want without your printer or your mold limiting you. They pop together easily, allowing for complex and flexible(not literally, but you're free to try) structures with ease. Since each tile measures under 140 mm in every direction, they can fit on almost any print bed. Even better, the scourge of 3D printing has been eliminated. They require no supports, and post-processing is as simple as a pair of scissors! Print a set, and mold your castle today!

Each tile molds either 100 or 84 millimeter flat surfaces, depending on if the face is molded. Every non-clip external face a 100x100 mm face, so squares are predominant. The clips also use triangles and circles, adding those geometric patterns to the list. An example of a mold has been shown among the gallery. Sadly, as I do not have access to a printer, I could not create an actual model, but the Onshape has a feature that allowed me to create the shown mold.

All 4 of the parts have been pre-oriented. The two different edge type tiles are necessary. Without both, you will not be able to close off some faces completely.

When printing these, I would recommend:
4 corners
14 edge tiles
2 semi-inverted edge tiles
13 edge tiles

Note: This creates the mold above. I would recommend calculating how many you need for your own molds, if you make any. It would be an unhappy day if you printed 7 corners and 10 edges and at the beach realized you needed another 10 edges or some main tiles.

When you print the tiles, DO NOT REORIENT THEM. Turn supports off as well. They are not necessary, as most printers can make the bridging. Turn on at your own risk. With the corner tile, in the face with 2 female connectors, there shall be a small amount of filament supporting the bridges in each. These can be trimmed with a pair of close-cutting scissors or other tool. Rafts can also be used, but they may be a trick to get off. Once you print the tiles, put them together and enjoy your castle!

Castle such as these were build with the outward walls at an angle to dissipate the inertia of incoming cannonballs. Instead of the cannonballs hitting the walls directly and causing as much damage as possible, the cannonballs would ricochet off of the wall and over the castle, causing considerably less damage.

The walls are at an angle to cause even greater difficulty in sieging the castles, as they would allow more archers along the walls of the castle to defend and reduce the area in which the opposition would be taking below, making it more likely for the archers to hit someone or something.

If anyone is interested, I'll gladly add details to the molds for you.

remixed_from.author: driggers
remixed_from.title: Micro Cloud Copter: Customizable Quadcopter Tricopter Hexacopter Octocopter Multirotor!

description.text:
Why

I loved the idea of the Ultimate Micro Quad (the original dreamcatcher as far as I can tell), and the customizable variant by driggers.

I wanted a customizable version (eg for different motor and board dimensions), but as much as I love the idea of OpenSCAD, I don't love the experience of using OpenSCAD to modify frame variables, especially in situations where heavy modification is necessary.

How

I decided to re-model the dreamcatcher idea in Onshape, where it can be graphically parametric. I've made the model public if you want to make your own copy.

The version I've uploaded here fits a Syma X1. I have a whole fleet of these at work, and I wanted to be able to upgrade/repair them without having to constantly be fiddling with the cheesy gearing and motor connectors on that model.

Notes

  • This model is more a re-work than it is a re-mix, given that I used the source material as inspiration, but re-drew the plans from scratch (many times).
  • I've made some changes to the idea of the original design. The most prominent is the motor mount, which retains the "pop-out" idea, but adds an integrated bottom to make it easier to ensure that motors are all at the same height, and to lower the center of gravity relative to the motors. I also added struts across the "wings", which keeps the model from buckling under pressure from the rubber bands that hold it together.
  • The motor on a Syma X1 is a 7x20mm brushed motor. Micro Motor Warehouse has the best replacements in that size.
  • Update 2015.08.17: I updated the motor mounts to be a bit taller, tighter, and to have fillets for added strength in a crash.
  • Update 2015.08.25: I updated the holder to have fully enclosed corners. You have to use a lanyard hitch to attach your rubber band, but it's much stronger when printed out of PLA.

I print this using Simplify3D, with a layer height of 0.3 mm in PLA, with about 15% infill.

I've attached the Simplify3D print profile so you can just import that if you use Simplify3D already (you should, it's great). It's the file called "Explo Makerbot 5th Generation Print Settings.fff"

title: Golf Cup for Miniature golf course

description.text:
This is a regulation size golf cup that I used for making my own miniature golf course. The lip around the cup is the same height as artificial turf so the ball does not change direction when you putt.

Another use could be a top hat. lol.

I designed it in Solidworks in about 30 minutes. Printed on a Z18 Makerbot at 0.1mm resolution. It looks and works absolutely great.

The cup is used in my course that is raised up 6 inches off the ground so I used a "hole saw" blade to cut into the plywood. I placed the turf down and then flipped the cup over and used a razor knife to cut the turf perfectly (perfect circle). Then I glued down the turf. After that you cut the hole with the hole saw blade and caulk the cup into place.

shadow box w/6mm glass insert, 1mm photo slot

This is a customizable Sub-Kick Microphone that I made.

Be sure to download the latest version before you print it. There are likely changes!

By default the .scad file is configured for a "Tang Band W6-1139SIF" speaker that I had kicking around. That's the one in the pictures.

  • When purchasing a speaker, look for a speaker that has a low resonant frequency (Think 20-60 hz kinda range).

  • Sealed back speakers are unsuitable for this application (I believe?).

Easiest to open the "sub_kick_maker.scad" file in OpenSCAD (freeware) and change the variables there rather than in the customizer.

You will require:

  • A Speaker
  • A Neutrik (or likely any brand) D Series XLR Male Jack
  • Some nuts and bolts
  • Some wires and solder
  • You'll likely also want to add a simple circuit to attenuate the signal that the sub-mic puts out by about 20 db.

Should require no support for printing when properly oriented.

remixed_from.author: AndrewBCN
remixed_from.title: Ultimate Greg's Wade's Geared Extruder - 30mm version

title: Ultimate Greg's Wade's Geared Extruder - Bowden version

description.text:
This is exactly the same as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:961630 except it is designed to feed filament into a Bowden pushfit connector.
The diameter of the Bowden pushfit connector is configurable in the source, by default it is 9.5mm. Filament diameter is fixed at 1.75mm, since using 3mm filament with a Bowden system is not recommended.
The extruder body can be rendered with or without a mounting bracket. Example code for a basic mounting bracket which can be screwed to a 2020 aluminum profile is included.

Everything else is exactly the same so please refer to the original 30mm version for details, attribution, comments, instructions, etc.

Again, complete OpenSCAD sources are available, including those for the fishbone gears.
Please be sure to read the source code and render the parts according to your setup before printing.

You might be wondering what is a button box. It is a simple device consisting of four

light touch switches, which can be used as input for a computer. The switches sit under each finger so they can be pushed with the tiniest effort and without moving your arm. Perfect for someone a physical disability such as muscular dystrophy.

An Arduino Leonardo is used to input the button presses to the computer, meaning each button can be programmed to do whatever you like. From keystrokes to mouse commands and joystick commands.

The button box is on instructables.com as well. For detailed instructions go to http://www.instructables.com/id/Button-box-for-Disabled-unfinished-/

Another adaptation of Vivenda's excellent hearthstone Keys. I used Vivenda's Hearthstone 4 wins key (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:364510) again as the basis but modified my previous adaption published as Hearthstone arena key 5 wins. Separated the knife, duplicated, crossed and added. Using only Tinkercad, and manipulating the parts, this has become a huge file if you go to tinkercad to edit it, so expect it to take a while to load. Vivenda is the true artist. I just tinker.

Because of the stack of "stuff" on top the key, I loaded it into Simplify3D, embedded down half-way in the Z direction into the bed, so it was split length-wise. Printed that, then rotated the model in-place on the X axis by 180 degrees. Printed that. Cleaned the two half-prints and glued them together. Support is needed because of the overhangs, and it works better if a raft is used.

title: Pinch Valve Adapters for a Coleman 12 Volt pump

description.text:
Pinch Valve Adapters for a Coleman 12 Volt pump for blowing up air an mattress, Dingy and other inflatable things.

I kept losing my adapters every time I go camping, so I thought I'd model and print out my own bright pink versions. They should be easy to find in the grass. If I do end up losing them I can always print more now. :)

I made one specific to fit my Dingy which has a screw on valve. I think it is a common size and others might find it useful.
I printed it out in PLA, you will need to add support where the open groove section of the end that connects to the pump.

comments.text: Thanks for this. Found a cheap inflator missing the attachments. Figured someone out there made a model!

description.text: This spool holder can hold any sized roll less than 10.5 CM tall. This is made from all 3d printed parts.

To assemble, print 1 base, 2 rollers, and 2 adjustable roller holders. Start by attaching a roller to the base by feeding the 1.75mm filament through the holes in the side of the base and through the roller until it reaches the other side. Than cut the end so it sticks out of both ends about 2 mm. Do the same with a second roller and the 2 filament roller holders. Your done! Adjust the second roller and put your filament on top.

OPTIONAL:
if you want to decrease the probability of the filament coming out of the roller get a Tupperware container and put some acetone and ABS scraps inside. it should make a paste. put some on the outside of the base to connect it to the filament. Do the same to the other side.

Sci-fi chemical plant storage tank for tabletop wargames. This model is a preview of a full model pack of the Colmar chemical plant (Pyre Light). Visual design inspired by MechWarrior 2 building models. Originally designed for 6mm BattleTech (1/285), using 1 hex = 1.75" (1.5in with .125" gutter, similar to HeroScape terrain). Can be scaled to fit other game scales.

If working in mm in your slicing software, scale the .STL by 25.4.

Feedback welcome - please comment!

Multiply scale by 25.4 if working in mm.

Designed for single-extruder .5mm ABS filament. Object is manifold with minimized undercuts and should print successfully with any thermoplastic filament extrusion, powder substrate (3DSystems / zCorp), or similar additive process.

No hex base included. Not suitable for small children.

I needed a little token of some kind to represent poison while playing Magic: The Gathering. I searched Google Images and found a great skull image made by David Lanham at The Iconfactory (from stickper pack one: http://iconfactory.com/freeware/preview/stkr1 ). I converted it to SVG with Inkscape, made the border perfectly round, and put it through OpenSCAD. The final coins are 1" in diameter and about 2mm thick. I used the multiply function of Skeinforge and was able to print 9 of them on a single plate on my ToM in ~25 minutes. At that size, the triangle nose didn't come out correctly, but all and all they're quite cute. Special thanks to David Lanham who was kind enough to let me post this design, I just put it on a coin.
If you don't have to colors of plastic to print with, you can just color the background with a sharpie. Looks quite good.

description.text:
This is a collection of things that can be used to mathematically enhance your sand castle designs. It comes in five parts:

  1. Rollers: to add texture to the sand.
  2. Mathematical shape molds: Your favorite 3D shapes in sand.
  3. Polygon Cookie Cutters: For all your polygon needs.
  4. Bucket molds
  5. The sigil.

Everything is made with math to play with math. All of my design work is done with Mathematica. So everything is created from formulas as parametric plots.

It has been an interesting summer of design and redesign. We started with the notion of flat panels to add interesting patters to castle walls. But we had several issues with the panels. These issues included the printer not printing properly (the panels had a tendency to warp), and not cutting into the sand well enough. So we moved to the idea of the rollers.

Rollers: The hole in the middle of each roller is designed so that the roller will slide onto a paint roller handle. You will find a large variety of brick patterns covering most of the wall paper groups and all of the frieze groups. The frieze group rollers are shorter and are subtle. The elevation of the bricks in the middle create the desired symmetry.
There are two rollers based on a space filling Hilbert curve that create a labyrinth. After all - every self respecting castle has a Labyrinth.
One of the rollers has a couple windows so that you can roll your castle walls with a fancy grid pattern and places for its inhabitants to look out.
A couple of the rollers were inspired by designs that I saw at a tour of the Washington State Capital building in Olympia Washington.
My daughter is doing her annual decorated cake for the county fair and decided that one of the rollers could be used to texture part of the cake. Then her boyfriend decided that he would do a decorated cake in the shape of a castle. The walls and courtyard he exciting patterns rolled into them. So, if your not out rolling these in the sand then you could be in the kitchen rolling your cake frosting, or pie crusts or who know how many other things.

Shape Molds
I wanted to have molds that created mathematical objects. You take two halves, scoop up some sand and squeeze it together. Then you take the haves off one by one to expose your object. Being a polyhedral guy I started with the platonic solids. Then for kicks I did one of the Archimedean solids and my favorite Johnson solid. It is not every day that you see a triangular hebesphenorotunda, and even more rare that you see one at the beach. Then I went for some of the smooth objects like a sphere, torus cylinder and hyperboloid. These shape molds work great for dressing up your castle.

Cookie Cutters
There are two types of cookie cutters. First, there are the polygon cutters. I have included both my earlier design that has handles and the more recent version without handles. I found that the handles were flimsy and people pushed too hard on them. Once the handles had broken off I found that I liked better. So the second version has no handles. There are polygons with 3 up to 12 sides. All have the same edge length so that you can tile the plane with them.
The second type of cutters are the arches, windows and doors. Each arch is a catenary curve (upside down hyperbolic cosine curve). I use this shape because it is self supporting. Sandstone arches are always in this shape (take a tour on Lake Powell in Utah/Arizona and you will see them all over the place). The arch doorway and the windows (in the window roller) have this same shape, but the lintel has a point that comes from a hyperbolic sine of an absolute value function.

Bucket Molds
The classic sand castle mold is a shaped bucket that you fill with sand, pack it down and then flip upside down to take the sand out. I had started work on a couple designs that would incorporate some fractal ideas but nothing of this sort is finished by the entry deadline. I do have simpler designs ready. One is inspired by my wife who insisted that we should have some kind of top for towers that had merlons with heights related to the abacabadabacaba pattern. This pattern is related to binary counting and has fractal properties, so it fit in with what I was trying to do. The other bucket mold (called "Twin Hills") is the surface from which we created the sigil. It is a parabolic hyperboloid with some exponential bumps added to it. There is one wide low bump, Two tall upward bumps and two medium downward bumps.

The Sigil:
This is the contour plot of the twin hills. It is the only thing from the original flat designs that survived. Just find a smooth patch of sand and press it in.

At the Beach:
We went to the beach 3 times this summer to test the different designs and see what we could do. The beach we go to is Birch Bay Washington. At high tide there is no beach, but when the tide goes out it goes way out. At low tide there is miles of beach. So, we have to look for a day with a really low tide in the middle of the day. We get there about 3 hours before low tide. This gives about 6 hour before the tide comes back in and washes away all castles.
The first day we built a big box, and filled it with sand and water, packing it as we went. Then we removed the box and started carving. We did not have much printed yet but it was clear that the flat panels had their problems. The flat panel worked best on a round tower. So we figured that a roller might work better on the flat castle walls.
The second day just me testing out the cookie cutters and shape molds. I also tested some ideas for a big castle. With a couple screw drivers and some string I constructed an ellipse in the sand. Inside the ellipse I laid out a 3.6.3.6 tiling and used the cookie cutters to make designs in the hexagons. I also place some of the shapes on the triangle tiles as if they were statues in a garden.
On the third beach day we again constructed an ellipse. This time we also constructed an hyperbola with the same foci. We built our box at one end of the ellipse (using the focus as one corner of the castle. The ellipse determined the moat and the two parts of the hyperbola were the roads entering and exiting the castle. THis gave a lot of room for different people to try different things. By this time we had printed many of the items that I had designed, so people could experiment. It was a fun day but the tide returned before we had finished. We decided that we had constructed something that looked like castle ruins. Mathematical castle ruins

The Mathematics:
One theme of my career has been to make people say "WOW" when looking at something mathematical. My training is in geometry, so this challenge was right up my alley. By putting mathematical patterns onto castle walls (by simply rolling it into the sand) people would stop to look. Did they learn any math? I don't know. But their experience at the beach was enhanced because of it. And I'd be willing to bet that the three kids that spent the most time looking and asking questions will always remember that day at the beach, because they saw something different. Was it math or was it just cool? Well - Math is just cool.

description.text: Yes, finally, from the original iPhone gun case maker, comes the semi-auto for iPhone 6! Long requested for, the compact Ruger LCP + iPhone 6 design = yet another mean way to provoke much discussion and philosophical thought on the merits of gun/tech ownership and the folly of bringing this case into a bank, hospital or school. This version is static - no moving parts, it is exactly what is described - just a case. Should you want the version with the magazine, trigger-operated volume buttons, etc, you can see it on http://shpws.me/Jz0e. Due to overhangs, you may need to split apart the STL and print separately with supports for FDM. For SLS, you can print directly.

This gun case is designed around an iPhone 6 case and the Ruger LCP Compact. This has been very successfully printed on SLS, and it will snap together with no tools at all. Just be mindful where you pull this out :-)

Should you want the version with the magazine, trigger-operated volume buttons, etc, you can see it on http://shpws.me/Jz0e. Due to overhangs, you may need to split apart the STL and print separately with supports for FDM. For SLS, you can print directly.

This is a support for a USB GPS/cellephone charger.
It is designed to fit to the ignition lock of a Honda NX 650 Dominator motorcycle.

The support is designed to be pushed with force on the ignition lock.
However to fix it very firmly on the ignition lock, you have to make a small hole horizontally in which you can screw a self threading screw pointing to the ignition lock

comments.author: lughjs

author: NGR923

description.text:
Based on a useful everyday tool created by Phei, I decided while creating this customizable object to form a sort of tutorial out of it in the form of 7 progressive scad files, zipped up.

Starting from Phei's included diagram, I first parameterised, then built primitives, moved them, rounded off some corners, and finally added in a fudge factor (tolerance) for the key grab point to the desk based on my experience with my printer.

The result is a tool which can create any sized hook for any desk to hold any item. Simply tweak according to need in the customizer.

comments.text: do you get the Ideea from me :D http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:254562
comments.author: Windpower

comments.text: Actually I got the initial design from this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:966446. I can't comment on his inspiration as it's not listed. Really though, this was more about a) making it easily customizable online to those without programming experience, and in addition to provide those more adventurous souls with a set of steps to show how to take a simple model, parameterise it, and make it accessible via the online customizer to others. Hope that helps explain :)
comments.author: Windpower

comments.text: That's awesome! I actually wanted to do the whole thing in OSCAD, too, but lack the knowledge. Thanks!

comments.text: Glad you liked it :)

description.text:
Camera mount for a PZ0420m Camera that will attach nicely to the top of a zuul, this is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945862

Use M3x35mm Bolts and M3 locknuts to mount it to your frame :)

I have already had one highspeed upside down crash with this on and the camera was well protected :)
